These secret attachments are of innumerable kinds, all of which are secretly clung to by the discriminations of ordinary foolish people. These discriminations are like silkworms making cocoons, using the threads of their own thoughts to entangle themselves and others, clinging to existence and non-existence with a firm and secret desire.
Great Wisdom!
In this, there are no secret or non-secret characteristics, because Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas see all dharmas as abiding in quiescence and are without discrimination.

If one understands that all phenomena are only what is seen by the mind, without external objects, all are the same as signlessness. In accordance with observation, whether there is discrimination or secret attachment, all are seen as tranquil. Therefore, there are no signs of secrecy or non-secrecy.
Great Wisdom!
In this, there is no bondage and no liberation. Only those who do not understand reality see bondage and liberation.
Why is this?
Because whether all phenomena exist or not, if one seeks their essence, it cannot be found.
Furthermore, Great Wisdom!
Foolish ordinary beings have three kinds of secret bonds, namely:
greed, anger, delusion, and the love that comes to life together with greedy joy. These secret bonds cause sentient beings to continue to be reborn in the five destinies;
if the secret bonds are severed, then there are no signs of secrecy or non-secrecy.
Furthermore, Great Wisdom!
If there is attachment to the three conditions that combine, the secret bonds of the various consciousnesses will arise in sequence.
Because of attachment, there are secret bonds. If one sees the three liberations apart from the three combined consciousnesses, all secrets will not arise.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Unreal false discrimination is called the characteristic of secrets;
If one can know it as it is, the net of all secrets will be cut off.
The foolish are unable to understand, following words to grasp meaning;
It is like a silkworm in a cocoon, deludedly binding itself.
At that time, the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Dá¹›á¸hamati addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the World-Honored One has said:
'By various minds discriminating all dharmas, the self-nature of dharmas does not exist, this is just false imagination.' World-Honored One!
If it is just false imagination without any dharmas, will not all defiled and pure dharmas be completely destroyed? The Buddha said:
MahÄsattva!
It is so, it is so!
As you have said.

All foolish ordinary beings discriminate phenomena, but the nature of phenomena is not like this. This is merely false grasping without any nature or characteristics. However, the noble ones, with the eye of holy wisdom, truly know and see the self-nature of phenomena.
Mahamati said:
If the noble ones see with the eye of holy wisdom that there are natures of phenomena, not with the heavenly eye or the fleshly eye, and do not discriminate like foolish ordinary beings,
how can foolish ordinary beings be free from discrimination?
Because they are unable to understand the teachings of the sages.
World-Honored One!
They are neither deluded nor undeluded.
Why is this?

Because they do not see the teachings seen by the sages, because the sage's view is far removed from the characteristics of existence and non-existence, and because the sages are not like the discriminations of ordinary beings in this way, and because it is not the realm of their own practice and characteristics;

They also see that there are natures and characteristics of dharmas, as they appear due to false grasping of natures, because they do not speak of causes or no causes, and because they fall into views of the natures and characteristics of dharmas.
World-Honored One!
The remaining objects are not the same as this, and thus there is the fault of infinite regress. Who can understand the natures and characteristics of dharmas?
World-Honored One!
The natures and characteristics of dharmas do not depend on discrimination. How can it be said that there are dharmas due to discrimination?
World-Honored One!
The characteristics of discrimination are different from the characteristics of dharmas. The causes are not similar. How can dharmas be due to discrimination?
For what reason do ordinary foolish people's discriminations not accord with existence, yet they say:
'In order to cause sentient beings to abandon discrimination, it is said that the characteristics of dharmas as seen by discrimination do not exist in this way.'
World-Honored One!

Why do you cause sentient beings to be free from the attached dharmas of the views of existence and non-existence, yet again become attached to the realm of holy wisdom and fall into the view of existence?
Why do you not speak of the dharmas of quiescence, emptiness, and non-existence, but speak of the matter of the self-nature of holy wisdom?
The Buddha said:
Mahamati!
I am not saying that falling into the view of existence is not the dharma of quiescent emptiness.
Why is it so?
Because I have already spoken of the matter of the self-nature of holy wisdom.

I speak of holy matters for sentient beings who have been attached to existence since beginningless time, so that when they hear of the quiescent dharma, they will not be frightened, and will be able to realize the quiescent dharma of emptiness as it is. Free from deluded appearances, they will enter the principle of consciousness only, know that what they see has no external dharmas, realize the three gates of liberation, attain the seal of suchness, see the self-nature of dharmas and understand the realm of the holy, and be free from all attachments to existence and non-existence.
Furthermore, Mahamati!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should not establish that all dharmas are completely non-arisen.
Why is it so?
Because all dharmas are originally non-existent, and because the characteristics of arising are produced in that doctrine.
Furthermore, MahÄmati!
The statement that all dharmas are non-arisen is self-contradictory.
Why is it so?
Because that doctrine arises in dependence on something else;
Moreover, that doctrine is included within all dharmas, because the characteristic of non-arising is also non-arisen;
Moreover, that doctrine is accomplished through its parts;
Moreover, that doctrine that existent and non-existent dharmas are non-arisen is included within all dharmas, because the characteristics of existence and non-existence are also non-arisen;
Therefore, the doctrine that all dharmas are non-arisen is self-contradictory.
It should not be established in this way, because there are many faults in the parts;
Because the causes and different characteristics are mutually dependent;
Like non-arising, all dharmas are empty and without self-nature in the same way.
MahÄmati!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should say that all dharmas are like illusions and dreams, because they are seen and unseen, and because all are merely appearances of delusion, except for those who are foolish and would become terrified.
Great Wisdom!
Foolish ordinary beings fall into views of existence and nonexistence. Do not let them become frightened and turn away from the Great Vehicle.
At that time the World Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
No intrinsic nature, no speaking, no events, no basis;
Foolish ordinary beings falsely discriminate, with evil thoughts like a corpse.
All dharmas are unborn, established by non-Buddhists;
Because what they have is born, not formed from conditions.
All dharmas are unborn, the wise do not discriminate;
Because their doctrines arise from causes, this cognition is then destroyed.
Just as the eyes have myodesopsia, falsely seeing floating hairs;
All dharmas are also like this, foolish ordinary beings falsely discriminate.
The three realms of existence are only provisional names, without any real substance;
Based on this, there are provisional designations, discriminations, and false conceptual thoughts.
Provisional names and various characteristics agitate the mind and consciousness;
The Buddha's disciples have transcended this and roam without discrimination.
Taking the characteristics of water where there is no water arises from thirst and craving;
The foolish and ignorant see phenomena as such, but the sages are not like this.
The sages see purity and give rise to the three liberations;
Far removed from arising and ceasing, they always practice in the realm of no characteristics.
Cultivating the realm of no characteristics is also neither existent nor non-existent;
Existence and non-existence are both equal, and therefore the noble fruits arise.
How are phenomena existent and non-existent?
How do they become equal?
If the mind does not understand phenomena, the inner and outer will be agitated;
Once understood, they are equal, and the characteristics of agitation will then cease.
At that time, the great being Bodhisattva MahÄsattva again addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

As the Buddha has said, if one knows that objects are merely provisional names and utterly unobtainable, then there is nothing to grasp. Because there is nothing to grasp, there is also no grasper. Because both the grasped and the grasper are non-existent, one does not give rise to discrimination. This is called wisdom.
World-Honored One!

Why is it that wisdom cannot attain objects? Is it because it cannot understand the meaning of sameness and difference of the specific and general characteristics of all dharmas, and therefore it is said to be unobtainable?
Is it because the specific and general characteristics of dharmas are of various kinds and mutually conceal each other, and therefore they are unobtainable?
Is it because they are obstructed by mountains, cliffs, rocks, walls, curtains, screens, and barriers, and therefore they are unobtainable?
Is it because they are too far away, too close, or because the old, young, blind, and others with incomplete faculties are unobtainable?

If one does not understand the meaning of the identity and difference of the specific and common characteristics of all dharmas, and therefore says one does not attain, this is not called wisdom, it should be ignorance, because there is an object but one does not know it.

If it is because the specific and common characteristics of all dharmas are various and different, mutually concealing each other, and therefore one does not attain, this also is not wisdom, because knowing the object is called wisdom, not not knowing.

If it is because of being covered by mountains, cliffs, walls, curtains, screens, or barriers, being extremely far or near, or being old, young, blind, or dim-sighted, and therefore one does not know, that also is not wisdom, because there is an object but wisdom is incomplete and one does not know.
The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!
This is truly wisdom, not as you say. What I say is not a hidden teaching.

I say that the objects are only provisional names and cannot be obtained, because one realizes that they are only what is seen by one's own mind, and the existence or non-existence of external dharmas. Wisdom is ultimately without attainment in this. Because of non-attainment, the appearances do not arise. Entering the three gates of liberation, the essence of wisdom is also forgotten;

It is not like all conceptual ordinary beings, who from beginningless time have been perfumed by conceptual proliferation, and are attached to the various forms and characteristics of external dharmas, whether they exist or not. Knowing in this way is called not knowing. Not understanding that all dharmas are only what is seen by the mind, they are attached to the self and what belongs to the self, and discriminate between objects and cognition. Not knowing whether external dharmas exist or not, their minds dwell in the view of annihilation.
In order to cause them to abandon such discrimination, it is said that all dharmas are established by the mind alone.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
If there is something that wisdom does not perceive in the object,
That is neither knowledge nor non-knowledge, and is called a false conception.
The infinite mutual concealment, obstruction, and distance;
Wisdom cannot see, this is called wrong knowledge.
The obscurity of the faculties of the old and young, yet there are actually objects;
Unable to give rise to wisdom, this is called wrong knowledge.
Furthermore, Mahamati!

Foolish ordinary beings, deluded by the illusions of beginningless false evil thoughts, do not understand the real and the spoken Dharma, and cling to external characteristics in their expedient teachings, unable to cultivate the pure and real Dharma that transcends the four propositions.
Mahamati said:
So it is, so it is!
It is truly as the Honored One has taught.

Please explain to me the real Dharma and the spoken Dharma, so that I and all Bodhisattva-Mahasattvas may attain skill in these two Dharmas, which cannot be entered by non-Buddhists and the Two Vehicles.
The Buddha said:
Listen carefully!
I will explain it to you.

The TathÄgatas of the three times have two kinds of dharmas, namely:
The spoken Dharma and the true Dharma.
The spoken Dharma refers to speaking various skillful means in accordance with the minds of sentient beings;

The true Dharma refers to the practitioner's mind-manifestation, free from all discriminations, not falling into the categories of sameness, difference, both, or neither, transcending all mind, thought, cognition, and consciousness, in the realm of self-realized holy wisdom, free from the characteristics of associated views of causes and conditions, unknowable by all non-Buddhists, Å›rÄvakas, and pratyekabuddhas who fall into the two extremes. This is called the true Dharma.
You and all bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should cultivate and study these two kinds of dharmas well.

I speak of two kinds of dharmas, namely the spoken teachings and the true reality;
The spoken teachings are shown to ordinary beings, the true reality is for the practitioner.
At that time, the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Great Wisdom again addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

Once the TathÄgata said that the words and theories of the RÄká¹£asa spells and treatises only lead to worldly wealth and benefits, not to the benefits of the Dharma. One should not associate with, serve, or make offerings to them.
Why did the World-Honored One say this?
The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!

The words and theories of the RÄká¹£asa spells and treatises only use flowery language to deceive ordinary people, conforming to worldly false speech. They do not accord with the meaning or principles, cannot lead to the realization of the true realm, cannot awaken to all dharmas, always fall into the two extremes, and cause oneself to lose the right path, also causing others to lose it, transmigrating through the destinies and never escaping.
Why is this?
Because they do not understand that all dharmas are only seen by the mind, but cling to external objects and increase discrimination.

Therefore, I say that the words and phrases of worldly treatises adorned with reasons and analogies only deceive fools and cannot liberate them from the afflictions of birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, and so forth.
Great Wisdom!
Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, is well-versed in various treatises and has composed treatises himself.
One of his disciples manifested the body of a dragon, went to the palace of the devas, and established a thesis, saying:
'KauÅ›ika!
If I lose the debate with you, I will smash your thousand-spoked wheel;
if you lose, I will cut off each of your heads to apologize for your defeat.'
Having said this, he used the methods of debate to defeat Indra and smash his thousand-spoked wheel, then returned to the human realm.
Great Wisdom!

Worldly discourses are adorned with reasons and analogies, and can even manifest the form of a dragon, using wonderful words and phrases to confuse the devas and asuras, causing them to become attached to views of arising and ceasing, let alone humans.
Therefore, Mahamati!
One should not associate with, serve, or make offerings to them, because they are able to create the causes of suffering in the world.
Mahamati!
The worldly discourses only speak of the realm of bodily awareness.
Mahamati!

Those worldly discourses have hundreds of thousands of words and phrases, but in the latter age, evil views will lead to division and the collapse of the heterodox assemblies. They will split into many factions, each clinging to their own causes.
Mahamati!

The other non-Buddhists are unable to establish the Dharma teachings. Only the LokÄyatas, with their hundreds of thousands of phrases, extensively explain the characteristics of innumerable differentiated causes, which are not in accordance with reality, and they themselves do not know that they are deluding the world.
At that time, Mahamati said:
World-Honored One!
If the treatises composed by the LokÄyatas, adorned with various words and phrases and reasons, are attached to their own doctrines and are not the true Dharma, and are called non-Buddhist,

The World-Honored One also speaks of worldly matters, saying that various kinds of phrases and words extensively explain that the heavenly beings and humans from all the lands in the ten directions gather here. This is not the Dharma realized by one's own wisdom.
Does the World-Honored One also speak the same as the non-Buddhists?
The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!
I do not speak of the world, nor do I speak of coming and going. I say that all dharmas do not come and do not go.
Great Wisdom!
Coming is the gathering and arising, going is the destruction and cessation. Not coming and not going, this is called non-arising and non-cessation.
Great Wisdom!
What I speak is not the same as the non-Buddhists who fall into discrimination.
Why is it so?

Because there is no attachment to the existence or non-existence of external dharmas. Only one's own mind is realized, and the two graspings are not seen. One does not engage in the realm of characteristics and does not give rise to discrimination. One enters the gate of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness and is liberated.
Great Wisdom!
I remember once when I was staying in one place, a worldly discourse brahmin came to me and suddenly asked me,
'Gautama!
Are all things created?'
I then replied,
'Brahmin!
All things created are the first worldly discourse.'
He further asked me,
'Are all things not created?'
I then replied,
'All things not created are the second worldly discourse.'
He further asked,ğŸ”½'Are all things permanent?
Are all things impermanent?
Are all things born?
Are all things unborn?'
I then replied,
'This is the sixth worldly discourse.'
He further asked,
'Are all things the same?
Are all things different?ğŸ”½Are all things together?
Are all things not together?
Are all things born from various causes and conditions?'
I then replied:
'This is the eleventh worldly discussion.'
He further asked:
'Are all things determinable?
Are all things indeterminate?
Is there a self?
Is there no self?
Is there this world?
Is there no this world?
Is there the other world?
Is there no other world?
Is there liberation?
Is there no liberation?
Is it momentary?
Is it not momentary?
Are space, nirvana, and non-analytical cessation created?
Are they not created?
Is there an intermediate state?
Is there no intermediate state?'
I then replied:
'Brahmin!
Such are all your worldly discussions, not what I teach.
Brahmin!

I teach that the three existences arise from beginningless evil habits of conceptual proliferation, not realizing that what is seen is only one's own mind, and grasping at external phenomena that are actually unattainable.
Like the non-Buddhists say, I and the three unities of sense faculties and objects give rise to cognition;

I am not like this. I do not speak of causes, nor do I speak of no causes. I only speak of dependent arising based on the false mind appearing as grasper and grasped, which cannot be fathomed by you or others who grasp at a self.'
Mahamati!
Space, nirvana, and non-analytical cessation, these three numbers are originally without substance, let alone speaking of what is made and what is not made.
Mahamati!
At that time, the worldly brahmin again asked me,
'Are the three existences caused by ignorance, craving, and karma?
Or are they without a cause?'
I said,
'These two are also worldly discussions.'
He further asked me,
'Do all dharmas enter their own characteristics and common characteristics?'
I then replied,
'This is also a worldly discussion.'
Brahmin!
Even the slightest movement of the mind and consciousness and discrimination of external objects are all worldly discussions.
Great Wisdom!
At that time, the brÄhmans asked me again, saying:
'Are there any that are not worldly discussions?'
All the arguments and various phrases and analogies of the non-Buddhists are not all from my teachings.'
I replied:
'There are.
They are not accepted by you, not accepted by the world, not not spoken, and various phrases and meanings correspond, not not corresponding.'
They asked again:
'Are there any worldly acceptances that are not worldly discussions?'
I answered:
'There are.
But they are not known by you or any non-Buddhists.
Why is this?
Because of falsely discriminating and clinging to external dharmas.'
If one can understand that all dharmas of existence and non-existence are all seen by one's own mind, not giving rise to discrimination and not grasping external objects, abiding in one's own place.
Abiding in one's own place means the meaning of non-arising. What does not arise?
It does not give rise to discrimination.
This is my Dharma, not yours.
Brahmin!

In brief, wherever the mind consciousness goes and comes, dies and is reborn, seeks and clings, whether receiving, seeing, touching, or abiding, grasping various characteristics and combining in continuity, giving rise to attachment to craving and causes, are all your worldly discussions, not my Dharma.'
Great Wisdom!
The worldly discussion Brahmins asked like this, and I answered like this. They did not ask me about my own school's true Dharma, and left in silence, thinking:

'The Å›ramaá¹‡a Gautama has nothing to respect. He says that all dharmas are unborn, signless, without causes or conditions, and are only seen through the discriminating mind. If one can understand this, discrimination does not arise.'
Great Wisdom!
You now also ask me about this meaning: 'Why, when one associates with those who discuss worldly matters, does one only obtain material benefits and not the benefits of the Dharma?'
Great Wisdom said:
'What are the meanings of material and Dharma?'
The Buddha said:
'Excellent!
You are able to contemplate this meaning for the sake of future sentient beings.ğŸ”½Listen attentively!
Listen attentively!
I will explain it for you.
Great Wisdom!

What is called material is tangible, perceptible, graspable, and enjoyable, causing attachment to external objects, falling into the two extremes, increasing craving, and giving rise to birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress. I and all Buddhas call it material gain, obtained through associating with worldly discussions.
What is the benefit of the Dharma?

It means understanding that dharmas are the mind, seeing the two kinds of no-self, not grasping at characteristics, being without discrimination, well understanding the grounds, being free from mind, thought, and consciousness, being consecrated by all Buddhas, fully receiving and practicing the ten inexhaustible vows, and attaining mastery over all dharmas. This is called the benefit of dharmas.
Because of this, one does not fall into any views, disputes, discriminations, or the two extremes of permanence and annihilation.
Great Wisdom!
The worldly discussions of non-Buddhists cause foolish people to fall into the two extremes, namely:
Permanence and annihilation. Accepting the doctrine of no cause leads to the view of permanence, and the destruction of causes leads to the view of annihilation.
I say that one who does not see arising, abiding, and ceasing is said to attain the benefit of dharmas. This is called the difference between the two, wealth and dharmas.
You and all Bodhisattva-MahÄsattvas should diligently contemplate.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Subduing and gathering sentient beings, using precepts to subdue evils;
Wisdom eliminates all views, and liberation grows.
The false teachings of non-Buddhists are all worldly discourses;
They wrongly conceive of agent and action, and cannot establish themselves.
Only my own school does not cling to subject and object;
I teach my disciples to leave worldly discourses.
The grasper and the grasped are only mind, and do not exist;
The two kinds are both manifestations of the mind, and neither eternalism nor annihilationism can be obtained.
As long as the mind flows and moves, it is then worldly discourse;
When discrimination does not arise, this person sees their own mind.
The coming is seen as the arising of phenomena, and the going is the non-appearance of phenomena;
Clearly understanding coming and going, one does not give rise to discrimination.
Existence, non-existence, what is made, what is not made;
This world, the other world, and so forth, are all the dharmas of worldly discourses.
At that time, the great being Bodhisattva MahÄsattva again addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
The Buddha speaks of nirvÄá¹‡a, but what kind of dharma is taken as nirvÄá¹‡a?
Yet the various non-Buddhists have various discriminations.
The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!
The way the various non-Buddhists discriminate nirvÄá¹‡a is all not in accord with the characteristics of nirvÄá¹‡a.ğŸ”½Listen attentively!
Listen attentively!
I will explain it for you.
Great Wisdom!

Some non-Buddhists say that seeing dharmas as impermanent, not craving for objects, the aggregates, realms, and sense bases ceasing, the mind and mental factors not appearing, not thinking of past, present, or future objects, like a lamp going out, like seeds rotting, like a fire extinguished, all grasping not arising, discrimination not occurring, they give rise to the notion of nirvÄá¹‡a.
Great Wisdom!
It is not called nirvÄá¹‡a by the destruction of seeing;
Or they say reaching a place is called attaining nirvÄá¹‡a, the thought of objects gone like the stilling of wind;
Some say that not seeing the perceiver and the perceived is called nirvana;
Some say that not giving rise to discrimination, whether of permanence or impermanence, is called attaining nirvana;

Some say that discriminating various characteristics gives rise to suffering, and that one is unable to know what is manifested by one's own mind. Because of not knowing, one is afraid of characteristics and seeks for the absence of characteristics, deeply giving rise to fondness and taking it as nirvana;

Some say that being aware of the specific and general characteristics of internal and external phenomena, and the indestructibility of the nature of past, present, and future, is the thought of nirvana;
Some reckon that the self, person, sentient being, life, and all dharmas are indestructible, and take it as the thought of nirvana;
Again, there are non-Buddhists who, lacking wisdom, reckon there is intrinsic nature, and that a person seeks to transform the given to create all things, taking it as nirvana;
Some non-Buddhists reckon that merit and demerit are exhausted, some reckon that without wisdom the afflictions are exhausted, and some reckon that the creator is real, taking it as nirvana;

Some say that sentient beings arise from each other, and this is the cause, with no other cause. Because of their ignorance, they are unable to understand. Because of their lack of understanding, they grasp it as nirvÄá¹‡a;
Some conceive of attaining the true path and mistakenly take it as nirvÄá¹‡a;
Some conceive of the union of the recipient and the recipient, whether of the same nature or different natures, together or not together, and grasp it as nirvÄá¹‡a;

Some conceive that things arise from nature, such as the colorful plumage of peacocks and the sharpness of thorns, and that where treasures are born, various treasures emerge. Who could have created such things?
They then grasp nature itself as nirvÄá¹‡a;
Some say that understanding the twenty-five principles leads to nirvÄá¹‡a;
Some say that being able to accept the six elements and protect sentient beings leads to nirvÄá¹‡a;
Some say that time gives rise to the world, and when time passes, it is nirvÄá¹‡a;ğŸ”½Some grasp existence as nirvÄá¹‡a;
Some conceive of non-existence as nirvÄá¹‡a;
Some are attached to the idea that existence and non-existence are nirvana;
Some think that all things are no different from nirvana, and form the idea of nirvana.
Mahamati!

There are also those who, unlike what is taught by the non-Buddhists, roar the lion's roar of the Great Master of All Knowledge, saying that one can understand that all is manifested by the mind alone and does not take external objects, to be far removed from the four propositions and abide in the true view, not falling into the two extremes and free from subject and object, not entering into any valid cognition and not attached to reality, to abide in the Dharma realized by the holy wisdom, to awaken to the two kinds of egolessness, to be free from the two kinds of afflictions, to purify the two kinds of hindrances, to transform and cultivate the various stages, to enter the Buddha stage, to attain the various great samadhis such as the illusion-like, to forever transcend mind, thought, and cognition, and to be called attaining nirvana.
Mahamati!
Those non-Buddhists falsely conceive and do not accord with reason, and are rejected by the wise. They all fall into the two extremes and form the idea of nirvana.

There is neither abiding nor emerging in this. Those non-Buddhists all give rise to false awareness based on their own doctrines, contradicting reason and accomplishing nothing. They only cause the mind to run and scatter back and forth, with none attaining nirvÄá¹‡a.
You and all bodhisattvas should abandon them.

Each with different discriminations,ğŸ”½Are only false imaginations,
Without the means of liberation.ğŸ”½Far from the various means,
Not reaching the place of no bondage,ğŸ”½Falsely giving rise to the thought of liberation,
Yet in reality there is no liberation.ğŸ”½The non-Buddhists' established doctrines,
With various different understandings,ğŸ”½They are all without liberation,
Foolishly discriminating falsely.ğŸ”½All the foolish non-Buddhists,
Falsely seeing the doer and the done,ğŸ”½All attached to the discourse of existence,
Therefore there is no liberation.
The foolish delight in discrimination, not giving rise to true wisdom;
Words are the basis of the three realms, true cessation is the cause of ending suffering.
Just as an image in a mirror, though appearing, is not real;
In the mirror of the mind of habitual tendencies, the foolish see duality.
Not understanding it is only mind's manifestation, they give rise to two kinds of discrimination;
If one knows it is only mind, discrimination will not arise.
Mind is precisely the various [phenomena], far removed from the imagined and the characterized;
Just as the foolish discriminate, though seeing, there is no seeing.
